    Author:
    Ask Hetland Berentsen, Magnus Måbø Nystad

    • Field Detail

      • status

        private GlassCannon.RadarStatus status
        The status of the scanner.

        GlassCannon uses three different states to divide its tasks into three phases. a phase will decide what actions and routines to perform and how to react to different inputs.

        If the robot is in the GlassCannon.RadarStatus.SCANNING state, the robot will scan around itself, logging all the robots it found during the sweep.

        If the robot is in the GlassCannon.RadarStatus.TARGETING state, the robot will select a target and scan towards where the target is predicted to be.

        If the robot is in the GlassCannon.RadarStatus.ENGAGING state, the robot will lock the scanner onto the target so that it can be reasonably sure it has the freshest statistics of the target at all times.

        See Also:
        GlassCannon.RadarStatus

      • targetName

        private String targetName
        The name of the the target.

        GlassCannon uses target discrimination to select a robot to target. When logging all the robots, GlassCannon will select a target based on some criteria and set the targeted robot as targetName.

        targetName is used to get the statistics from STATISTICS.

        See Also:
        STATISTICS, pickTarget()

      • consecutiveTicksTargetNotFound

        private int consecutiveTicksTargetNotFound
        A counter for how many ticks the target was not found.

        When GlassCannon is in the GlassCannon.RadarStatus.ENGAGING phase, it will keep track of how many ticks have passed not having scanned targetName. If targetName was not found for a certain amount of ticks, GlassCannon will disengage and pick a new target.

        See Also:
        targetName, update(), GlassCannon.RadarStatus.ENGAGING

      • STATISTICS

        private final HashMap<String,​RobotStatistics> STATISTICS
        A list of statistics for all the robots in the game.

        Logs some relevant statistics about all the robots. If a Robot has not been scanned this update, a predicted statistic for this update will be auto-generated.

        If a Robot dies, or is thought to be dead, the statistics will not be cleared, but instead the statistics for the presumably dead Robot will be marked as dead, and will no longer generate predictions.

        See Also:
        targetName, update(), logRobot(ScannedRobotEvent), RobotStatistics

      • SCANNED_ROBOTS_PER_TICK

        private final HashSet<String> SCANNED_ROBOTS_PER_TICK
        A set of Robot names scanned in one update.

        The set of names is filled up during the update, and after all the Robot names have been logged and the update is completed, the set is emptied.

        See Also:
        update(), logRobot(ScannedRobotEvent)

      • SCANNED_ROBOTS_DURING_SCAN_PHASE

        private final HashSet<String> SCANNED_ROBOTS_DURING_SCAN_PHASE
        A set of Robot names scanned during the GlassCannon.RadarStatus.SCANNING phase.

        The set of names is filled up during the scanning phase, which lasts several ticks. After all the radar has completed its sweep, GlassCannon will update the statistics off the robots, based on whether they were scanned or not during that specific sweep.

        If a Robot was not found during the SCANNING phase, it will be marked as inactive. Inactive robots are robots that are not known to be dead or alive, and will be prioritized less than other robots when picking a target.

        If a Robot was not found during the SCANNING phase, and it had already been marked as inactive, it can confidently be declared dead.

        See Also:
        update(), logRobot(ScannedRobotEvent), GlassCannon.RadarStatus.SCANNING

      • virtualBullets

        private final ArrayList<Transform> virtualBullets
        A list of virtual bullets.

        When GlassCannon sees a discrepancy in the energy statistic of a Robot, it can assume the robot has fired a bullet. When this happens, some virtual bullets are generated based on the transform history of this. We can assume the Robot will try to either use direct, linear or circular interception, and as such, this can avoid the positions of where these bullets would be if they were real.

        See Also:
        update(), virtualizeBullets(Transform)

    • Method Detail

      • run

        public void run()
        Class initializer.

        Sets the event priority such that this can react to killing an enemy and scanning the robots at the end of the update.

        Sets the gun and radar to be entirely independent.

        Specified by:
        run in interface Runnable
        Overrides:
        run in class Robot

      • update

        private void update()
        The main method.

        update() is the method that will be called at the end of a update.

        At the end of a update, the positions of the virtual bullets and unscanned robots will be updated to a predicted position. These positions can be used when deciding where to move and where to scan.

        After having updated all the positions, this will decide where to move next.

        The main logic of update() is decided by the status, and will react accordingly.

        When in the GlassCannon.RadarStatus.SCANNING phase, this method will check whether or not the radar has completed its sweep. If it has, then it will update the statistics of all the robots that were not found during the SCANNING phase.

        When in the GlassCannon.RadarStatus.TARGETING phase, this method will check whether or not the radar has scanned the target. If it has, then move to the ENGAGING phase. If however the target was not found, and the radar has completed its sweep, then we can confidently disengage with the target.

        When in the GlassCannon.RadarStatus.ENGAGING phase, this method will check whether or not the radar has scanned the target. If it has not, then count the amount of consecutive ticks targetName was not found. If the target has been missing for 3 or more ticks, then we can confidently disengage. Regardless whether or not the target was found during any specific update, update() will try to predict the targets position and lock the radar to an area with some leeway. For every update, the gun will aim towards the predicted position, and once the gun is sufficiently accurate, it will fire a bullet. Once the gun has fired, this begins the SCANNING phase again while waiting for the gun to cool down.

        At the very end of a update, SCANNED_ROBOTS_PER_TICK will be cleared.

        See Also:
        targetName, STATISTICS, virtualBullets, SCANNED_ROBOTS_PER_TICK, SCANNED_ROBOTS_DURING_SCAN_PHASE, aimGun(), disengage(), lockScanner(), GlassCannon.RadarStatus

      • disengage

        private void disengage()
        Disengages from the target.

        Sets the target to inactive, picks a new target and starts the GlassCannon.RadarStatus.SCANNING phase.

      • aimGun

        private void aimGun()
        Aims the gun at a target. Estimates a future position and turns the gun to that direction.

        If the target is not moving, or not moving a lot on average. The robot will aim towards the targets current position.

        If the target is moving in a straight line, the robot will intercept the target in a straight line. circularInterception() is reliant on division by the angle, and when the angle is 0, the method cannot estimate a coordinate. linearIntercept is faster than circularIntercept() and should be used as often as possible before it.

        If the target is moving in a curve, the robot will assume the target will continue to move in the same curve.

        See Also:
        linearIntercept(Vector2, Vector2, Vector2), circularIntercept(Vector2, Vector2, Vector2, Vector2, long)

      • lockScanner

        private void lockScanner()
        Locks the scanner to the area around the target Robot.

        Calculates the maximum angle that the radar can sweep in one update and constrains it with some uncertainty factor so that if the target moves outside of the bounds, the radar has enough room to overshoot the target.

        See Also:
        getTargetStatistics()

      • linearIntercept

        private Vector2 linearIntercept​(Vector2 referenceFrame,
                                Vector2 coordinates,
                                Vector2 trajectory)
        Finds the intercept coordinates of a target. Uses lookahead to converge on a position where the bullet will hit the target. This method takes origo as its reference point, in order to generalize this method to use other reference points, transform all the relevant vectors such that the reference point becomes (0,0).

        Uses convergence to estimate the future position of coordinates to a degree of accuracy.

        A reversible function that can be applied to any reference frame.
        Parameters:
        referenceFrame - the coordinates to use as a reference frame.
        coordinates - the initial coordinates of a target.
        trajectory - the trajectory of a target.
        Returns:
        the coordinate to intercept.

      • circularIntercept

        private Vector2 circularIntercept​(Vector2 referenceFrame,
                                  Vector2 coordinates,
                                  Vector2 trajectory,
                                  Vector2 oldTrajectory,
                                  long deltaTime)
        Calculates a coordinate to intercept if a target is moving in a circle. To find the intercept coordinate, find the angular difference between two trajectories and account for the time difference. Use this angle to calculate the radius of a pivot vector. The angle of the vector should be perpendicular to the trajectory. When the pivot vector is rotated by the angle that was calculated, the arc-length is equal to the scalar of the trajectory vector.

        Uses convergence to estimate the future position of coordinates to a degree of accuracy.

        A reversible function that can be applied to any reference frame.
        Parameters:
        referenceFrame - the coordinate to use as a reference frame.
        coordinates - the coordinate of the target.
        trajectory - the direction and velocity of the target.
        oldTrajectory - the direction and velocity the target when the target was last calculated.
        deltaTime - the amount of ticks since oldTrajectory was calculated.
        Returns:
        a coordinate to intercept.

      • updateMovement

        private void updateMovement()
        Updates the movement.

        Calculates the forces applied from the enemy robots, virtual bullets, walls and target and applies the force to this.

        See Also:
        calculateForceVector(Vector2)

      • calculateForceVector

        private Vector2 calculateForceVector​(Vector2 coordinates)
        Calculates the force applied from a given coordinate. Assumes equal mass for all coordinates.
        Parameters:
        coordinates - the coordinates where the force originates.
        Returns:
        the force from the coordinate.

      • virtualizeBullets

        private void virtualizeBullets​(Transform robot)
        Virtualizes bullets so that this can avoid them.
        Parameters:
        robot - the position, trajectory and velocity of an enemy.

      • beginScanPhase

        private void beginScanPhase()
        Initializes the GlassCannon.RadarStatus.SCANNING phase.

        Sets the radar to scan 360 degrees.

        See Also:
        status, update(), GlassCannon.RadarStatus.SCANNING

      • beginTargetPhase

        private void beginTargetPhase()
        Initializes the TARGETING phase. Rotate the scanner to the targets expected position. Intentionally overshoots based on an uncertainty factor to ensure the target will most likely be found. If the target is not found during this phase, we can confidently disengage the target.
        See Also:
        onStatus(StatusEvent), GlassCannon.RadarStatus.TARGETING

      • beginEngagePhase

        private void beginEngagePhase()
        Initializes the ENGAGING phase. Rotate the scanner to overshoot the targets expected position. When the scanner overshoots the target, it will most likely produce a ScannedRobotEvent.
        See Also:
        onStatus(StatusEvent), GlassCannon.RadarStatus.ENGAGING

      • getTargetStatistics

        private RobotStatistics.Statistic getTargetStatistics()

        the statistics of the target this update.
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if the target has not been initialized.
        See Also:
        STATISTICS

      • onRobotDeath

      • onScannedRobot

        public void onScannedRobot​(ScannedRobotEvent e)
        This method is called when your robot sees another robot, i.e.  when the robot's radar scan "hits" another robot.

        Assumes the enemy has fired a bullet if the energy of the scanned robot is discrepant to the expected energy level.

        Specified by:
